results.title: After Ferguson Shooting, State of Emergency Is Declared
results.abstract: St. Louis County declared a state of emergency Monday, as charges were filed against an 18-year-old who was shot by the police during protests on the anniversary of the killing of Michael Brown.
results.byline: By JOHN ELIGON and MITCH SMITH

multimedia.caption: Protesters marched in St. Louis on Monday after a weekend of commemorations of the killing a year ago of Michael Brown.
Protesters marched in St. Louis on Monday after a weekend of commemorations of the killing a year ago of Michael Brown.

results.title: Black Activists Arrested
results.abstract: Two high-profile activists were among 56 people arrested during a civil disobedience protest.

multimedia.caption: The scholar and author Cornel West was arrested on Monday by the St. Louis Police during a protest outside the Thomas F. Eagleton Federal Courthouse.

results.abstract: On the anniversary of Michael Brown’s death, a police officers’ association in Columbia, Mo., called Mr. Wilson “innocent, but persecuted.”

results.title: 50 Years After Riots, Watts Is in Recovery
results.abstract: A symbol of racial tensions after riots broke out in 1965, Watts, a neighborhood in Los Angeles, has made strides in relations between the police and the community. But it is no utopia.

multimedia.caption: The Watts Towers. It has been 50 years since riots broke out on the streets in Watts for six days starting on Aug. 11, 1965.
The Watts Towers. It has been 50 years since riots broke out on the streets in Watts for six days starting on Aug. 11, 1965.
The Watts Towers. It has been 50 years since riots broke out on the streets in Watts for six days starting on Aug. 11, 1965.
The Watts Towers. It has been 50 years since riots broke out on the streets in Watts for six days starting on Aug. 11, 1965.

results.title: Fox News Journalist Says She Won’t Be Cowed by Trump
results.abstract: “This is a tough business,” Megyn Kelly, who moderated the first G.O.P. presidential debate last week, told viewers Monday. She brushed off Donald Trump’s comments, saying, “I’ll continue doing my job without fear or favor.”
results.byline: By JEREMY W. PETERS and DANIEL VICTOR

multimedia.caption: From left: Chris Wallace, Megyn Kelly and Bret Baier moderated the first Republican presidential debate Thursday on Fox News.
From left: Chris Wallace, Megyn Kelly and Bret Baier moderated the first Republican presidential debate Thursday on Fox News.

results.title: Trump Is ‘Emperor With No Clothes,’ Rand Paul Says
results.abstract: Lagging in the polls, Senator Rand Paul laid into Donald J. Trump, calling him “a bully” and an “empty suit,” and adding, “Somebody has to challenge him.”

results.title: Anger Rises Over Estimate of Colorado Toxic Water Spill
results.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency, typically charged with responding to toxic disasters, has claimed responsibility for unleashing a chemical brew into the Animas River.

multimedia.caption: People kayaking in the Animas River near Durango, Colo., last Thursday, in water colored from a mine waste spill. The river is now closed indefinitely, with visitors warned to stay out.

results.title: Story of Torture, Told in Drawings, Grips China
results.abstract: A man wrongly convicted in a shooting death hired an artist to depict scenes of the police tactics he said were used to force him to confess to a crime he did not commit.

results.title: Japan Restarts Reactor Following Fukushima Disaster
results.abstract: A power plant operator in southern Japan restarted a nuclear reactor on Tuesday, the first to begin operating under new safety requirements following the Fukushima disaster.

results.title: For Many in Spain, Economic Recovery Feels Like a Bust
results.abstract: The majority of the country’s new jobs are part-time and offer low wages, experts say, and some employees are expected to do unpaid work.

multimedia.caption: Angel Puyalón, 50, with his wife, at home in Zaragoza, Spain. He lost his job as an interior designer and has been unable to find work, so they rely on a food bank to eat and fear being evicted.
multimedia.copyright: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times

results.title: The Roanoke Island Colony: Lost, and Found?

results.title: NBC Retains Rights to Premier League in Six-Year Deal

results.abstract: A top 800-meter runner has refused to sign a document that requires American athletes to wear Nike gear at official team functions at the world championships, which begin Aug. 22 in Beijing.

results.title: Los Angeles Is a Frugal, if Not Flashy, Option for the 2024 Games
results.abstract: With some of the infrastructure already in place and ready to be reused, Los Angeles is considered the most likely American candidate to host the 2024 Olympics following the collapse of Boston’s bid.

results.title: Marin Cilic Struggles to Get Back Into Zone After U.S. Open Success
results.abstract: As the No. 14 seed last year, Cilic claimed his first Grand Slam title. But since then, he has been bothered by a shoulder injury and has yet to reach the final of any tournament.

results.title: Government Explains Push for Lance Armstrong’s Medical Records
results.abstract: The government said the records from Armstrong’s 1996 cancer treatments could prove just how far he was willing to go to conceal performance-enhancing-drug use.

results.title: Officials Deny Dirty Water Made Rowers in Rio Sick
results.abstract: United States officials confirmed that 15 members of the team fell ill after the world junior championships but said that was not abnormal in international events.

results.title: Arena League Teams in Las Vegas and New Orleans Fold
results.abstract: A league announcement said the Las Vegas Outlaws and the New Orleans VooDoo had ceased operations. The decision leaves the league with 10 teams.

results.title: Frank Gifford, Star for the Giants and in Broadcast Booth, Dies at 84
results.abstract: Gifford was a Hall of Fame running back and receiver who personified the Giants’ glory years of the late 1950s and early ’60s and then became a mainstay on television.
results.byline: By RICHARD GOLDSTEIN and BRUCE WEBER

results.title: How 14 Indicted FIFA Officials Currently Stand
results.abstract: Updating the legal status of the soccer and sports marketing officials charged in the FIFA corruption case.

results.title: After Sydney Seau, Football Hall of Fame Policy Will Be Tested Again
results.abstract: By giving Sydney Seau an abbreviated forum to speak on behalf of her father, the Pro Football Hall of Fame showed the folly of an exclusionary policy for dead inductees.

results.title: Los Angeles Proposes $4.1B Budget if Olympic Candidate
results.abstract: If the city of Los Angeles becomes the U.S. candidate for the 2024 Olympics after Boston's recent drop from contention, the organizers' proposed budget for the Summer Games would be $4.1 billion plus a $400 million contingency, a senior adviser to Mayor Eric Garcetti said Monday.

results.title: A Ukrainian Border Town Once Fenced by Soviets Blossoms Into a Shopper’s Paradise
results.abstract: Since 2005, a pedestrian crossing has drawn a surge of Slovakian visitors to a small Ukrainian village, where consumer goods are considerably cheaper.

multimedia.caption: Shoppers from Velke Slemence, Slovakia, returning to their country after a shopping trip to Mali Selmentsi, Ukraine. In 2005, the nations' governments allowed a pedestrian-only crossing to be cut through the border fence.
multimedia.copyright: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

results.title: Ex-Officer in Chinese Army Receives Suspended Death Sentence in Graft Case
results.abstract: The inquiry into the former senior officer, Lt. Gen. Gu Junshan, found that he had bought military promotions and pocketed millions of dollars through procurement contracts.

results.title: German Journalists Celebrate as Treason Inquiry Is Dropped
results.abstract: The investigation of Markus Beckedahl and André Meister for publishing secret government plans for Internet surveillance had stoked a public uproar.

results.title: Indonesian Court Rejects Sex Abuse Suit Against International School
results.abstract: The plaintiffs had claimed that janitors and educators repeatedly abused a 6-year-old boy at a prestigious private school popular with expatriates.

multimedia.caption: Ferdinand Tjiong, an Indonesian teaching assistant, center, and Neil Bantleman, a Canadian administrator, right, have been sentenced to 10 years in prison for sexual assault.

results.title: Gun Battle Erupts Outside U.S. Consulate in Istanbul
results.abstract: The attack was one of several violent episodes across the country, which some attributed to an uptick in clashes between Turkish security forces and Kurdish militants.

results.title: Afghan President Points Finger at Pakistan After Bombings in Kabul
results.abstract: After a car bombing on Monday continued a wave of attacks, President Ashraf Ghani accused Pakistan of failing to prevent Taliban gatherings in its territory.

multimedia.caption: Police officers at the site of a deadly car bombing Monday near the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan. Attacks in Kabul over the past four days have left almost 70 people dead and hundreds wounded.

results.title: Stampede in India Kills 10 Pilgrims Attending Hindu Festival
results.abstract: About 20 pilgrims were injured when a mob tried to force its way through a line of tens of thousands at a Hindu festival in the state of Jharkhand, a police official said.

results.title: Inside Syria: Kurds Roll Back ISIS, but Alliances Are Strained
results.abstract: Even as Kurds are assisting in the campaign against the Islamic State in Syria, Turkey, a latecomer to the U.S.-led mission, is also bombarding Kurdish insurgent positions.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: South Korea Accuses the North After Land Mines Maim Two Soldiers in DMZ
results.abstract: The South Korean military said that two of its soldiers were wounded by mines planted near their post on the South’s side of the Demilitarized Zone.

multimedia.caption: South Korean soldiers on patrol near the site of land mine explosions in the Demilitarized Zone last week. One soldier lost a leg; the other lost both.

results.title: Japan Restarts Reactor After Break Due to Fukushima
results.abstract: A power plant operator in southern Japan restarted a nuclear reactor on Tuesday, the first to begin operating under new safety requirements following the Fukushima disaster.

results.title: K-Pop Fans Swoon During East Coast KCON
results.abstract: Fans flocked to the East Coast debut of KCON, a one-day festival for all things hallyu, the Korean wave of culture sweeping into the West.

results.title: Widespread Child Sexual Abuse Case Rocks Pakistan
results.abstract: Allegations that a gang of men abused at least 280 children, and sold videos of the abuse, have led to seven arrests.

results.abstract: The authorities ordered that two high-profile activists from the radical right, Meir Ettinger and Eviatar Slonim, be imprisoned without charge or trial.

results.title: As South Korean Villages Empty, More Primary Schools Face Closings
results.abstract: When Nogok Primary closes this spring, it will become one of thousands of schools in the country that have shuttered as industrialization and education draw people to cities.

multimedia.caption: Chung Jeong-su, above, at Nogok Primary. He spends recess throwing paper planes. Farmers sent children to the school hoping they would escape their backbreaking work.
multimedia.copyright: Jean Chung for The New York Times

results.title: Change in Militant Tactics Puts Tunisians on Edge
results.abstract: Recent attacks have provoked a security crackdown that has Tunisians wondering if they can fight terrorism without giving up hard-won freedoms.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A Tunisian police officer guarded the site of an attack in June at the Imperial Marhaba hotel in the resort town of Sousse. Militants appear to have changed tactics to specifically target tourists.

results.title: 29 Are Killed in Afghanistan as Bombing Targets Militia
results.abstract: At least 29 people were killed and 19 others wounded in the bombing in the northern Afghan province of Kunduz, Afghan officials said Sunday.
results.byline: By NAJIM RAHIM and MUJIB MASHAL
